{{Infobox musical artist | name = Smoky Babe | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Robert Brown | alias = | birth_date = 1927
[[Itta Bena, Mississippi]], United States | death_date = June 20, 1975 | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Louisiana blues]], [[Piedmont blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1960s | label = | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Smoky Babe''' (1927 – June 20, 1975){{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1970.html |title=The 1970s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} was an [[United States|American]] [[acoustic blues]] [[guitarist]] and [[singing|singer]]. He is variously described as a [[Louisiana blues]], [[Piedmont blues]] and [[List of blues revival musicians|blues revival]] [[musician]], whose [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] career was restricted to a couple of recording sessions in the early 1960s.{{cite web|author=[[Cub Koda]] |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/smoky-babe-mn0000032645/biography |title=Smoky Babe | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} His most noteworthy [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] were "Going Downtown Boogie," and "Ain't Got No Rabbit Dog." ==Career== He was born '''Robert Brown''', in [[Itta Bena, Mississippi]], United States. Smoky Babe was recorded by [[Harry Oster]] of [[Louisiana State University]] in 1960 and 1961,{{cite book | first= John | last= Broven | year= 1992 | title= South to Louisiana | edition= 3rd | publisher= Pelican Publishing Company | location= Louisiana | isbn= 1-55553-355-8 | page= 117}}{{cite web|url=http://sundayblues.org/page/2 |title=Big Road Blues - Part 2 |publisher=Sundayblues.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} and the results were released by the Folk Lyric, [[Bluesville Records|Bluesville]] and [[Storyville Records|Storyville]] [[record label|labels]].{{cite web|author=Stefan Wirz |url=http://www.wirz.de/music/smokybab.htm |title=Illustrated Smoky Babe discography |publisher=Wirz.de |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} Outside of his recordings little is known of his life. The definite circumstances concerning his demise in June 1975 are also unclear. His song, "Boogy," was included on the [[compilation album]], ''Blues Roots: Give Me The Blues'' (1979);{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/brewefrm.htm |author=Stefan Wirz |title=Illustrated Jim Brewer discography |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=2014-01-29}} whilst "Hottest Brand Goin'" and "Locomotive Blues" appeared on the 1998 collection, ''The Bluesville Years, Vol. 9: Down the Country Way.''{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/blackfrm.htm |author=Stefan Wirz |title=Illustrated Scrapper Blackwell discography |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=2014-01-29}} ==Discography== *''Smoky Babe and his Friends: Hot Blues'' (1961) - Folk-Lyric, [[77 Records]], [[Arhoolie Records|Arhoolie]] *''Hottest Brand Goin'' (1961) - Bluesville *''Smoky Babe, Herman E. Johnson: Louisiana Country Blues'' (1997 ) - Arhoolie ==See also== *[[List of blues revival musicians]] *[[List of Louisiana blues musicians]] *[[List of Piedmont blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://archive.org/details/SmokyBabe Smoky Babe recordings at archive.org] {{Persondata | NAME = Brown, Robert | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Smoky Babe | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American [[acoustic blues]] guitarist and singer | DATE OF BIRTH = 1927 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Itta Bena, Mississippi]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = June 20, 1975 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Smoky Babe}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:1975 deaths]] [[Category:People from Itta Bena, Mississippi]] [[Category:Blues musicians from Mississippi]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Blues revival musicians]] [[Category:Louisiana blues musicians]] [[Category:Piedmont blues musicians]]
